Question Text: Which of the following terms describe Ethernet addresses that can send one frame and is delivered to multiple devices on the LAN? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Multicast address
b. Broadcast address
c. Unicast address
d. IP address
e. MAC address
LLM Explanation: In this scenario, the terms that describe Ethernet addresses that can send one frame and are delivered to multiple devices on the LAN are multicast address and broadcast address. A multicast address is used to send one frame to multiple devices that are interested in receiving that specific frame. A broadcast address is used to send one frame to all devices on the network. Unicast address is used to send one frame to a specific device. An IP address is used for network layer addressing, and a MAC address is a unique identifier assigned to network interfaces for communications at the data link layer.

Question Text: ___________ is a set of rules determining how network devices respond when two devices attempt to use a data channel simultaneously and encounter a data collision.
Choices:
a. CSMA/CA
b. TCP/UDP
c. TCP/IP
d. CSMA/CD
LLM Explanation: CSMA/CD (Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection) is a set of rules used in Ethernet networks to determine how network devices respond when two devices attempt to use a data channel simultaneously and encounter a data collision. With CSMA/CD, devices listen to the network before transmitting data to avoid collisions. If a collision is detected, devices use a backoff algorithm to retransmit data after a random time interval.

Question Text: Ethernet standard ___________ BASE-T defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling.
LLM Explanation: The Ethernet standard that defines Gigabit Ethernet over UTP cabling is 1000BASE-T. The '1000' in 1000BASE-T represents the speed of 1000 Mbps or 1 Gbps, which is Gigabit Ethernet.

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields allows devices on the network to easily synchronize their receiver clocks?
Choices:
a. Frame Check Sequence
b. Data and Pad
c. Start Frame Delimiter
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: The field that allows devices on the network to easily synchronize their receiver clocks is the Preamble. The Preamble field in the IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header is used to help devices on the network synchronize their receiver clocks before data transmission begins. It consists of a 7-byte pattern of alternating 1s and 0s, which helps the receiving devices detect the start of a frame.

Question Text: The host sends packets to its default gateway if the ____________ IP address is in a different subnet than the host.
Choices:
a. Destination
b. Unicast
c. Broadcast
d. Source
LLM Explanation: The correct option is 'a. Destination'. When a host sends packets to a destination IP address that is in a different subnet than the host itself, it will forward the packets to its default gateway. The default gateway is responsible for routing packets to destinations outside the host's local subnet.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Application TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. Ethernet
c. TCP
d. IP
LLM Explanation: SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) resides in the Application layer of the TCP/IP model. SMTP is responsible for sending and receiving email.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Transport TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. TCP
b. IP
c. Ethernet
d. SMTP
LLM Explanation: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) operates at the Transport layer of the TCP/IP model. It provides reliable, connection-oriented communication between devices.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Internet TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. IP
b. Ethernet
c. TCP
d. SMTP
LLM Explanation: IP (Internet Protocol) resides in the Internet TCP/IP Architecture layer as part of the Network Layer (Layer 3). TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) also resides in the Internet TCP/IP Architecture layer as part of the Transport Layer (Layer 4). Ethernet operates at the Data Link Layer (Layer 2) and SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) operates at the Application Layer (Layer 7) of the OSI model, not in the Internet TCP/IP Architecture layer.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols resides in the Data Link & Physical TCP/IP Architecture layer?
Choices:
a. SMTP
b. TCP
c. Ethernet
d. IP
LLM Explanation: Ethernet protocol operates at the Data Link layer (Layer 2) of the TCP/IP model. It is responsible for the communication between devices on the same local area network (LAN) segment.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols is used from PC1 to learn information from some other device on the same network?
Choices:
a. DNS
b. ARP
c. DHCP
d. ping
LLM Explanation: The correct protocol used from PC1 to learn information from some other device on the same network is ARP (Address Resolution Protocol). ARP is used to map an IP address to a MAC address within a local network. DNS (Domain Name System) resolves domain names to IP addresses, DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) assigns IP addresses to devices on a network, and ping is used to test the reachability of a host on an IP network.

Question Text: If the devices below were connected with UTP Ethernet cables, which pairs of devices would require a straight-through cable? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Router and hub
b. Hub and switch
c. Switch and PC
d. Router and PC
LLM Explanation: A straight-through cable is used to connect devices that operate on different communication standards, such as connecting a router to a switch or a switch to a PC. Routers and switches use different pin configurations for transmitting and receiving data, hence requiring a straight-through cable for proper communication.

Question Text: Which of the following protocols are examples of TCP/IP data-link layer protocols? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. HTTP
b. SMTP
c. PPP
d. TCP
e. HTTPS
f. Ethernet
LLM Explanation:
The correct options for TCP/IP data-link layer protocols are PPP (Point-to-Point Protocol) and Ethernet. 
a. HTTP is an application layer protocol. 
b. SMTP is an application layer protocol. 
d. TCP is a transport layer protocol. 
e. HTTPS is an application layer protocol.

Question Text: Which of the following statements are functions of a routing protocol? (Choose two answers.)
Choices:
a. Learning routes and putting those routes into the routing table for routes advertised to the router by its neighboring routers
b. Forwarding IP packets based on a packetâ€™s destination IP address
c. Advertising known routes to neighboring routers
d. Learning routes for subnets directly connected to the router
LLM Explanation: Routing protocols are responsible for learning routes from neighboring routers and advertising known routes to those neighbors. Option a is correct as routing protocols learn routes from neighboring routers and put those routes into the routing table. Option c is correct as routing protocols also advertise known routes to neighboring routers. Options b and d are not functions of routing protocols. Forwarding IP packets based on destination IP address is the role of the routing table and data plane, not the routing protocols. Learning routes for subnets directly connected to the router is part of the routing table's function, not the routing protocols.

Question Text: When you open a web browser and type in the hostname www.examsdigest.com, your computer does not send an IP packet with a destination IP address www.examsdigest.com; it sends an IP packet to an IP address used by the web server for Examsdigest. TCP/IP needs a way to let a computer find the IP address used by the listed hostname. That method uses the Domain Name System (DNS).
LLM Explanation: The statement is true. When a user types in a hostname like www.examsdigest.com in a web browser, the computer needs to resolve this hostname to an IP address to communicate with the web server. This resolution is done through the Domain Name System (DNS), which maps hostnames to IP addresses.

Question Text: A __________________ address is an address that enables transmission to every node in a local network.
Choices:
a. MAC
b. Broadcast
c. Unicast
d. Multicast
LLM Explanation: A broadcast address is used to transmit data to all nodes in a local network. When a device sends data to the broadcast address, it is delivered to all devices within the network segment. This is commonly used for tasks like network discovery or sending information to all devices on the network simultaneously.

Question Text: TCP and ______________ are the two most commonly used TCP/IP transport layer protocols.
Choices:
a. HTTP
b. UDP
c. DNS
d. SMTP
LLM Explanation: The two most commonly used TCP/IP transport layer protocols are TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) and UDP (User Datagram Protocol). HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol), DNS (Domain Name System), and SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) are application layer protocols and not transport layer protocols.

Question Text: Which of the following IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer Fields provides a method for the receiving NIC to determine whether the frame experienced transmission errors?
Choices:
a. Start Frame Delimiter
b. Frame Check Sequence
c. Preamble
d. Data and Pad
LLM Explanation: The Frame Check Sequence (FCS) field in the IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Header and Trailer is used to provide a method for the receiving NIC to determine whether the frame experienced transmission errors. The FCS is a CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check) value that is calculated by the sending NIC based on the data in the frame. The receiving NIC recalculates the CRC value based on the received data and compares it to the FCS value in the frame to check for errors.
